comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: August, 1913: Before the Suffragette Caravan left New York for Boston, pulled by a balky horse that the ladies had named "Asquith," (after the British prime minister, who also proved balky on the woman suffrage question) the participants (three British suffragettes and an American Salvation Army colonel -- with tambourine) released several homing pigeons, whose flight home to Boston was supposed to precede and herald their own arrival in that city. Here is a contemporary newspaper clipping about the event: www.elizabethfreeman.org/PDF/suffrage/bostonPigeons_big.pdf

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content:
Wystan: Thanks for linking to the additional information on this event.

Thanks to other images in the Prints and Photographs Division's collections and information provided here in Flickr, we will be able to add the identities of the ladies in the photo, from L to R: Ida Craft, Elsie McKenzie, Vera Wentworth and Elisabeth Freeman.
